bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James E. Peabody, September 26, 1940

div1.p: Hench requests that Peabody ask the Welch Medical Library to permit him to borrow or copy Peabody's research material. He encloses a letter introducing himself to Peabody and describing his research on the yellow fever experiments and on Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James E. Peabody, September 26, 1940
div1.opener:
September 26, 1940
Dr. James E. Peabody
152 Harvard Street
Newtonville, Massachusetts
My dear Doctor Peabody:
div1.p:
On September 12, I wrote you the
enclosed letter, but before it was mailed, I had your
nice letter of September 10. I believe since then you
have received my letter of the 18th.

If I cannot get the bibliography from
Mr. R. Elwood Logan of the American Muesum of Natural
History, I will write to the Welch Medical Library. I
wrote them some time ago, asking them what material they
had, but have not heard from them. I would appreciate it
greatly if you would write to them, expressing your willingness
that I know what you left with them and perhaps suggesting
that I might borrow it and have photostatic copies made from
it. I can appreciate the great historical value of the
material you left with them, and I will see to it that
the best care is taken of it.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
